segment.source: Overview
segment.target: Overview

segment.source: If you want the ScanState and LoadState tools to use any of the migration .xml files, specify these files at the command line using the /i option.
segment.target: If you want the ScanState and LoadState tools to use any of the migration .xml files, specify these files at the command line using the /i option.

segment.source: Because the ScanState and LoadState tools need the .xml files to control the migration, specify the same set of .xml files for both the ScanState and LoadState commands.
segment.target: Because the ScanState and LoadState tools need the .xml files to control the migration, specify the same set of .xml files for both the ScanState and LoadState commands.

segment.source: However, you do not have to specify the Config.xml file with the /config option, unless you want to exclude some of the files and settings that you migrated to the store.
segment.target: However, you do not have to specify the Config.xml file with the /config option, unless you want to exclude some of the files and settings that you migrated to the store.

segment.source: For example, you might want to migrate the My Documents folder to the store but not to the destination computer.
segment.target: For example, you might want to migrate the My Documents folder to the store but not to the destination computer.

segment.source: To do this, modify the Config.xml file and specify the updated file with the LoadState command.
segment.target: To do this, modify the Config.xml file and specify the updated file with the LoadState command.

segment.source: Then the LoadState command will migrate only the files and settings that you want to migrate.
segment.target: Then the LoadState command will migrate only the files and settings that you want to migrate.

segment.source: If you leave out an .xml file from the LoadState command, all of the data in the store that was migrated with the missing .xml files will be migrated.
segment.target: If you leave out an .xml file from the LoadState command, all of the data in the store that was migrated with the missing .xml files will be migrated.

segment.source: However, the migration rules that were specified with the ScanState command will not apply.
segment.target: However, the migration rules that were specified with the ScanState command will not apply.

segment.source: For example, if you leave out an .xml file, and it contains a rerouting rule such as: , USMT will not reroute the files, and they will be migrated to C:data.
segment.target: For example, if you leave out an .xml file, and it contains a rerouting rule such as: , USMT will not reroute the files, and they will be migrated to C:data.

segment.source: To modify the migration, do one or more of the following.
segment.target: To modify the migration, do one or more of the following.

segment.source: Modify the migration .xml files.
segment.target: Modify the migration .xml files.

segment.source: If you want to exclude a portion of a component—for example, you want to migrate C: but exclude all of the .mp3 files—or if you want to move data to a new location on the destination computer, modify the .xml files.
segment.target: If you want to exclude a portion of a component—for example, you want to migrate C: but exclude all of the .mp3 files—or if you want to move data to a new location on the destination computer, modify the .xml files.

segment.source: To modify these files, you must be familiar with the migration rules and syntax.
segment.target: To modify these files, you must be familiar with the migration rules and syntax.

segment.source: If you want ScanState and LoadState to use these files, specify them at the command line when each command is entered.
segment.target: If you want ScanState and LoadState to use these files, specify them at the command line when each command is entered.

segment.source: Create a custom .xml file.
segment.target: Create a custom .xml file.

segment.source: You can also create a custom .xml file to migrate settings for another application, or to change the migration behavior to suit your needs.
segment.target: You can also create a custom .xml file to migrate settings for another application, or to change the migration behavior to suit your needs.

segment.source: For ScanState and LoadState to use this file, specify them on both command lines.
segment.target: For ScanState and LoadState to use this file, specify them on both command lines.

segment.source: Create and modify a Config.xml file.
segment.target: Create and modify a Config.xml file.

segment.source: Do this if you want to exclude an entire component from the migration.
segment.target: Do this if you want to exclude an entire component from the migration.

segment.source: For example, you can use a Config.xml file to exclude the entire My Documents folder, or exclude the settings for an application.
segment.target: For example, you can use a Config.xml file to exclude the entire My Documents folder, or exclude the settings for an application.

segment.source: Excluding components using a Config.xml file is easier than modifying the migration .xml files because you do not need to be familiar with the migration rules and syntax.
segment.target: Excluding components using a Config.xml file is easier than modifying the migration .xml files because you do not need to be familiar with the migration rules and syntax.

segment.source: In addition, using a Config.xml file is the only way to exclude the operating system settings from being migrated.
segment.target: In addition, using a Config.xml file is the only way to exclude the operating system settings from being migrated.

segment.source: For more information about excluding data, see the Exclude Files and Settings topic.
segment.target: For more information about excluding data, see the Exclude Files and Settings topic.

segment.source: Migration .xml Files
segment.target: Migration .xml Files

segment.source: This section describes the migration .xml files that are included with USMT.
segment.target: This section describes the migration .xml files that are included with USMT.

segment.source: Each file contains migration rules that control which components are migrated and where they are migrated to on the destination computer.
segment.target: Each file contains migration rules that control which components are migrated and where they are migrated to on the destination computer.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: You can use the asterisk () wildcard character in each of these files.
segment.target: You can use the asterisk () wildcard character in each of these files.

segment.source: However, you cannot use a question mark (?) as a wildcard character.
segment.target: However, you cannot use a question mark (?) as a wildcard character.

segment.source: The MigApp.xml file.
segment.target: The MigApp.xml file.

segment.source: Specify this file with both the ScanState and LoadState commands to migrate application settings.
segment.target: Specify this file with both the ScanState and LoadState commands to migrate application settings.

segment.source: The MigDocs.xml file.
segment.target: The MigDocs.xml file.

segment.source: Specify this file with both the ScanState and LoadState tools to migrate all user folders and files that are found by the MigXmlHelper.GenerateDocPatterns helper function.
segment.target: Specify this file with both the ScanState and LoadState tools to migrate all user folders and files that are found by the MigXmlHelper.GenerateDocPatterns helper function.

segment.source: This helper function finds user data that resides on the root of any drive and in the Users directory.
segment.target: This helper function finds user data that resides on the root of any drive and in the Users directory.

segment.source: However, it does not find and migrate any application data, program files, or any files in the Windows directory.
segment.target: However, it does not find and migrate any application data, program files, or any files in the Windows directory.

segment.source: You can modify the MigDocs.xml file.
segment.target: You can modify the MigDocs.xml file.

segment.source: The MigUser.xml file.
segment.target: The MigUser.xml file.

segment.source: Specify this file with both the ScanState and LoadState commands to migrate user folders, files, and file types.
segment.target: Specify this file with both the ScanState and LoadState commands to migrate user folders, files, and file types.

segment.source: You can modify the MigUser.xml file.
segment.target: You can modify the MigUser.xml file.

segment.source: This file does not contain rules that migrate specific user accounts.
segment.target: This file does not contain rules that migrate specific user accounts.

segment.source: The only way to specify which user accounts to migrate is on the command line using the ScanState and the LoadState user options.
segment.target: The only way to specify which user accounts to migrate is on the command line using the ScanState and the LoadState user options.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Do not use the MigUser.xml and MigDocs.xml files together.
segment.target: Do not use the MigUser.xml and MigDocs.xml files together.

segment.source: For more information, see the Identify File Types, Files, and Folders and USMT Best Practices topics.
segment.target: For more information, see the Identify File Types, Files, and Folders and USMT Best Practices topics.

segment.source: Custom .xml Files
segment.target: Custom .xml Files

segment.source: You can create custom .xml files to customize the migration for your unique needs.
segment.target: You can create custom .xml files to customize the migration for your unique needs.

segment.source: For example, you may want to create a custom file to migrate a line-of-business application or to modify the default migration behavior.
segment.target: For example, you may want to create a custom file to migrate a line-of-business application or to modify the default migration behavior.

segment.source: If you want ScanState and LoadState to use this file, specify it with both commands.
segment.target: If you want ScanState and LoadState to use this file, specify it with both commands.

segment.source: For more information, see the How to Create a Custom .xml File topic.
segment.target: For more information, see the How to Create a Custom .xml File topic.

segment.source: The Config.xml File
segment.target: The Config.xml File

segment.source: The Config.xml file is an optional file that you create using the /genconfig option with the ScanState command.
segment.target: The Config.xml file is an optional file that you create using the /genconfig option with the ScanState command.

segment.source: You should create and modify this file if you want to exclude certain components from the migration.
segment.target: You should create and modify this file if you want to exclude certain components from the migration.

segment.source: In addition, you must create and modify this file if you want to exclude any of the operating system settings from being migrated.
segment.target: In addition, you must create and modify this file if you want to exclude any of the operating system settings from being migrated.

segment.source: The Config.xml file format is different from that of the migration .xml files because it does not contain any migration rules.
segment.target: The Config.xml file format is different from that of the migration .xml files because it does not contain any migration rules.

segment.source: It contains only a list of the operating system components, applications, and the user documents that can be migrated.
segment.target: It contains only a list of the operating system components, applications, and the user documents that can be migrated.

segment.source: For an example, see the Config.xml File topic.
segment.target: For an example, see the Config.xml File topic.

segment.source: For this reason, excluding components using this file is easier than modifying the migration .xml files because you do not need to be familiar with the migration rules and syntax.
segment.target: For this reason, excluding components using this file is easier than modifying the migration .xml files because you do not need to be familiar with the migration rules and syntax.

segment.source: However, you cannot use wildcard characters in a Config.xml file.
segment.target: However, you cannot use wildcard characters in a Config.xml file.

segment.source: If you want to include all of the default components, you do not need to create the Config.xml file.
segment.target: If you want to include all of the default components, you do not need to create the Config.xml file.

segment.source: Alternatively, if you are satisfied with the default migration behavior defined in the MigApp.xml, MigDocs.xml, and MigUser.xml files, and you want to exclude only some components, you can create and modify a Config.xml file and leave the other .xml files in their original state.
segment.target: Alternatively, if you are satisfied with the default migration behavior defined in the MigApp.xml, MigDocs.xml, and MigUser.xml files, and you want to exclude only some components, you can create and modify a Config.xml file and leave the other .xml files in their original state.

segment.source: When you run the ScanState command with the /genconfig option, ScanState reads the other .xml files that you specify using the /i option to create a custom list of components that can be migrated from the computer.
segment.target: When you run the ScanState command with the /genconfig option, ScanState reads the other .xml files that you specify using the /i option to create a custom list of components that can be migrated from the computer.

segment.source: This file will contain only operating system components, applications, and the user document sections that are in both of the .xml files and that are installed on the computer when you run the ScanState command with the /genconfig option.
segment.target: This file will contain only operating system components, applications, and the user document sections that are in both of the .xml files and that are installed on the computer when you run the ScanState command with the /genconfig option.

segment.source: Therefore, you should create this file on a source computer that contains all of the components, applications, and settings that will be present on the destination computers.
segment.target: Therefore, you should create this file on a source computer that contains all of the components, applications, and settings that will be present on the destination computers.

segment.source: This will ensure that this file contains every component that can be migrated.
segment.target: This will ensure that this file contains every component that can be migrated.

segment.source: The components are organized into sections: Applications, WindowsComponents, and Documents.
segment.target: The components are organized into sections: Applications, WindowsComponents, and Documents.

segment.source: To choose not to migrate a component, change its entry to .
segment.target: To choose not to migrate a component, change its entry to .

segment.source: After you create this file, you need to specify it only with the ScanState command using the /Config option for it to affect the migration.
segment.target: After you create this file, you need to specify it only with the ScanState command using the /Config option for it to affect the migration.

segment.source: However, if you want to exclude additional data that you migrated to the store, modify the Config.xml file and specify the updated file with the LoadState command.
segment.target: However, if you want to exclude additional data that you migrated to the store, modify the Config.xml file and specify the updated file with the LoadState command.

segment.source: For example, if you collected the My Documents folder in the store, but you decide that you do not want to migrate the My Documents folder to a destination computer, you can modify the Config.xml file to indicate before you run the LoadState command, and the file will not be migrated.
segment.target: For example, if you collected the My Documents folder in the store, but you decide that you do not want to migrate the My Documents folder to a destination computer, you can modify the Config.xml file to indicate before you run the LoadState command, and the file will not be migrated.

segment.source: For more information about the precedence that takes place when excluding data, see the Exclude Files and Settings topic.
segment.target: For more information about the precedence that takes place when excluding data, see the Exclude Files and Settings topic.

segment.source: In addition, note the following functionality with the Config.xml file:
segment.target: In addition, note the following functionality with the Config.xml file:

segment.source: If a parent component is removed from the migration in the Config.xml file by specifying , all of its child components will automatically be removed from the migration, even if the child component is set to .
segment.target: If a parent component is removed from the migration in the Config.xml file by specifying , all of its child components will automatically be removed from the migration, even if the child component is set to .

segment.source: If you mistakenly have two lines of code for the same component where one line specifies and the other line specifies , the component will be migrated.
segment.target: If you mistakenly have two lines of code for the same component where one line specifies and the other line specifies , the component will be migrated.

segment.source: In USMT there are several migration policies that can be configured in the Config.xml file.
segment.target: In USMT there are several migration policies that can be configured in the Config.xml file.

segment.source: For example, you can configure additional ErrorControl, ProfileControl, and HardLinkStoreControl options.
segment.target: For example, you can configure additional ErrorControl, ProfileControl, and HardLinkStoreControl options.

segment.source: For more information, see the Config.xml File topic.
segment.target: For more information, see the Config.xml File topic.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: To exclude a component from the Config.xml file, set the migrate value to "no".
segment.target: To exclude a component from the Config.xml file, set the migrate value to "no".

segment.source: Deleting the XML tag for the component from the Config.xml file will not exclude the component from your migration.
segment.target: Deleting the XML tag for the component from the Config.xml file will not exclude the component from your migration.

segment.source: Additional Information
segment.target: Additional Information

segment.source: For more information about how to change the files and settings that are migrated, see the User State Migration Tool (USMT) How-to topics.
segment.target: For more information about how to change the files and settings that are migrated, see the User State Migration Tool (USMT) How-to topics.

segment.source: For more information about each .xml element, see the XML Elements Library topic.
segment.target: For more information about each .xml element, see the XML Elements Library topic.

segment.source: For answers to common questions, see ".xml files" in the Frequently Asked Questions topic.
segment.target: For answers to common questions, see ".xml files" in the Frequently Asked Questions topic.
